abstracts.cdata!:
The Higher Education Reform Project for
            Argentina had the following ratings: the outcome was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory. The
            lessons learned indicate that support of an already ongoing
            reform process facilitates implementation, provides
            legitimacy and increases commitment to project development
            objectives. Only following several years of hard work and
            trial and error was Comision Nacional de Evolucion y
            Acreditacion Universitaria (CONEAU) established as an
            integral part of Argentina's higher education system.
            Lack of clarification of roles and responsibilities during
            project preparation for collecting baseline and performance
            data makes it difficult to sustain momentum for maintaining
            indicators. Even limited investment, distributed based on
            transparent and objective procedures selection, can go a
            long way in stimulating a culture of change and quality
            improvement. As illustrated by the Asignacion de Recursos
            (AR) funding formula, linking components to increases in
            public subsidies makes implementation highly vulnerable to
            external shocks. The implementation of subprojects under the
            competitive fund went into implementation delays because
            there was no control over counterpart funding at the project level.
